												I'm glad I picked this game up. INFRA is as fun as it sounds, even if some features aren't fully implemented. The general concept is that you play a "structural analyst", reviewing municipal works for disrepair and safety violations. You have to manage the battery level of both your camera, which is your way of documenting violations, and your flashlight. Being able to explore sewers, tunnels, office buildings, and factories and finding every little cracked wall or broken catwalk is engaging, and I never felt tired by that. After all, you can go through the game just by walking; the documentation gameplay is entirely optional. This could be good or bad, depending on the player. I appreciated that the game stepped out of my way, and I never had a heads-up display or a minimap pointing me to every OSHA violation. At the same time, some small way to monitor how many of these issues you've found would be nice.The other aspect of the gameplay reminds me of Disaster Report or similiar games. Basically, as luck would have it these structures you explore are in such bad disrepair that they start to fall down around your head. You have to battle the environment as you try to escape before total collapse. Usually, this works well, and it's cool to see these big set pieces slowly falling to pieces. It also makes sense within the context of the story... they really should have sent someone out here a while ago. Speaking of story, there is an overarching narrative to tie everything together, and it's one of the weaker parts of the game. It's been done time and time again, and you already know it: greedy land developer puts profit in front of human lives, there's a web of corruption and coverups, blah blah blah. Thankfully, your access to the story is limited to text pick-ups and audio logs, so the game doesn't force you to buy in if you just want to play.Everything here just works. The environments are varied, detailed, and look really good. Sound design is sparse (thank you), so when the music ramps up during a collapse, you can feel the tension. The voice acting is serviceable, which isn't really a problem when your protagonist is a working engineer. I loved the game; I kept thinking it would end early as indie games sometime do, but at around 6 hours it's the perfect length to show you all it wants to show you and get out. I easily recommend it at both the $7 sale price and the full $15.

												A thoroughly enjoyable, beautiful exploration game with plenty of great ideas only lacking in polish and general quality assurance. Some of the puzzles throughout the game are brilliant, but others are really not that good (I'm looking at you, raft section and all the elecrified floor jumpathons). I like the scandinavian aesthetic as I am a Finn myself (really brought me back to my heydays in Kontula with the above ground segments) and I really loved the nature segments as well.Above all, the game really needs some solid hints. I got through most of the game without a hitch, but some solutions are not so obvious and could use for example the player's voice to guide through them. I think there should be a prelude "routine infrastructure case" before coming to the office, a small tutorial course where you need to photograph, flashlight and get used to the mazelike urbex gameplay of INFRA. The game could really use one where you learn some not-so-obvious things like stacking crates and such. I really loved the office, but only in hindsight as it's a bit too good at showcasing the gameplay elements...it's just too much too fast and might scare more casual players away.I gotta hand it to you Oskutin & friends, the level design is phenomenal. There are some really amazing vistas and you managed to squeeze everything out of Source. I loved the blast furnace tower. I really really loved the little landscapes near the dam and the little suburban canal section. Top marks on the hacker den too - that place was fun as hell to go through. The waterfalls, the dam, everything is so peaceful, serene yet manage to get the atmospheric 'spooky' factor to the max. The unpolishness is making this a bit of a tough sell. There's a LOT of spelling errors, confusing sentences and overall weirdness going about. In my playthrough, none of the audiologs worked so I didn't get much out of the storyline. I'll play it through again when part 2 is out (lovely cliffhanger by the way). You really need someone to fix those quirks in text and script when you get around finishing the entire experience.There are also quite a few bugs. Physics glitches, sound issues and such were thankfully quite fast patched, but there are some lingering issues that almost all pertain to the engine itself. There's a crane that can detach its load in late chapter 5 that can kill your playthrough unless you reload a checkpoint, if you do things in wrong order with a certain forklift. There's some inconsistencies in level design where that cool area you found might not go anywhere at all. There's the infuriating pixel-perfect-or-you're-dead raft section that makes me want to skewer the one who okay'd that through QA. I hope these gets fixed after part 2 is out, since these really destroy the immersion and experience.And boy, what an experience it is. I'm almost inclined to go romping around abandoned factories and facilities in real life after having so much fun exploring these urban ruins. The camera mechanic is genius, if only you'd give more batteries to play around with. The puzzles are creative and the nice crisis scenes you get from time to time are well thought out and executed. A phenomenal title focused solely on urbex and puzzling, beautifully laid out in an urban yet natural scandinavian wonderland. Few more spit shine polish elements and I'd give this a solid 10/10, but I'll have to go with 8/10, with one point out for repeated 'electrified water' and 'stack the boxes' gags and the second one for unpolishness and the infuriating raft section. Did I mention how I hated that part yet? Seriously, it is beyond terrible.Overall, 8/10, would heavily recommend. Hyvää työtä Suomen pojat! :D

												Fantastic game. The downsides to this game are the short distances needed to fall to you death. A lesser problem is the constant need for batteries for your only two items: Your camera and your flashlight. Use of these are very simple. Pull out the camera to snap pictures of decayed or damaged infrastructure. You're going to be taking a lot of pictures. The flashlight is exactly that; A flashlight. You either ran out which would suck or you never ran into a problem with battery supply.Another nitpick for me was the slow running speed and the amount of long hallways. This game requires you to back track at times. This was perhaps the most annoying part of the game as I usually don't take the time to smell the flowers.The goodside of this game is that it is an amazing exploration game with tonnes of interactive puzzles and a conspiracy theory developing as you play. The best part, in my opinion, is that all of it is completely skippable. You can leave broken things broken, you aren't actually required to take any pictures and the conspiracy is just a side plot for those who are interested. This gives it a huge amount of replayability in my book. I've played through the game twice and though I think I've seen all that I can, fixed all that I could I'm still going to replay it again. At first the voice acting sounded a little off. The voice actors are non-native speaking and all have a thick Finnish accent but half way through the first part the accent grew on me. It is such a shame that this game hasn't gotten as much attention as it should have. The game has a secret puzzles that expands throughout the whole game and, as far as I've checked, it hasn't even been solved yet (As of 23 April 2017). I am eagerly awaiting the release of part 3.

												I think "environmental puzzler" best describes Infra. As a structural analyst, you venture deep into the infrastructure of a city, gradually making your way through various factories, tunnels and facilities. Traversal problems are the main meat of the game - You need to figure out, repair and operate decrepit machinery to progress, pushing and turning dozens of buttons and valves.Some of the contraptions are rather complex, and combined with the fact that the levels in the game can get quite expansive, patience and perception are required. Be prepared to run around in circles every once in a while, since the game isn't in the habit of holding your hand at all.Other than your wits, nothing much else is required. There's absolutely no shooting or enemies of any kind, but you can easily die to a multitude of enrivonmental hazards. There are some sections that require precision jumping and swift actions, but they are relatively far and between. For the most part, you can take as long as you want to explore.Some of the industrial levels are quite good-looking especially considering that the game is running on Source, but Infra definitely doesn't put its best foot forward and the game begins by bombarding the player with some extremely dubious character models and seriously weak voice acting. Fortunately these are the only attempts at human interaction you'll have to endure during the playthrough, and things quickly get into the groove once you're alone in the rural areas.I was pleasanly suprised by the length of the game and the toughness of the puzzles - Infra took me nearly ten hours, which is a lot considering the low price of the game. You'll have to look past a lot of rough edges though; The game crashed on multiple occasions, and I even had to momentarily swap into windowed mode to get past a particularly nasty level-loading crash. More than that, there are a few map glitches that forced me to revert to a previous checkpoint because I got hopelessly stuck. Oh, and the achievements seem to work very sporadically.Anyhow, despite of its shortcomings, I enjoyed my time with Infra a lot. The environments of the game tell a way better story than the various memos sprinkled around, and there's a promise of Part Two coming in the future. I'll play that one as well for sure.

												Loiste Interactive: INFRA is the Steam debut for Loiste Interactive a small gaming development and self-publishing firm located in Finland. The game had humble beginnings as a Source Engine mod project  that eventually grew large enough to become its own fully fledged title.  The game drew a rabid fan base whilst it was in the Steam Greenlight program attracting more than 45,000 votes and peaking at #4 on the Greenlight Charts. It wasn’t until the developers understood just how popular their title was that they ultimately decided to create the company from that – until this point it was a group of friends who were working on their mod together. Soon thereafter thanks to some investment into the company the group were able to commit themselves to their project on a permanent full time basis.Pre-Steam Release Acclaim: To show just how popular INFRA had become the game received a number of nominations and awards during its development cycle beginning in 2011 with selection to the top one hundred “Mod of the Year” list by ModDB, earning Greenlit status the following year on Steam and peaking with a nod from IndieDB as a top one hundred selection to “2014 Indie of the Year Awards.”A grand beginning: The first episode in the INFRA episodic adventure, part two will be free for purchasers of the first part, averages about ten hours in play. You play the role of a structural analyst whose tasked with the job of navigating, and hopefully surviving, a brutal labyrinth. As it says in the Steam Description, it is a gun-free puzzle adventure. Intelligence and strategy are awarded as you work your way through some of the most rewarding interactive puzzles to be seen in gaming in recent times. It’s an ambitious opening act that offers highly rewarding gameplay.Large maps that truly inspire you to explore: Almost from the very beginning you will be surprised at just how large the maps in the game are. Although I found the office section to be more than a little tedious  – it’s main purpose  is to serve as a tutorial – I was surprised at just how large the area was. This continues right throughout the episode. They are all highly detailed featuring a number of different potential routes and offered a feeling of an open world better than some true open world games. Each area is filled with puzzles and unique game play that really does make you feel that you’re not repeating the same things over and over again. The game design has been very well thought out. The maps provide you ample opportunities to explore and to try different ideas with all of this feeling very rewarding. I quite enjoyed the distinct looks and sounds of the various areas. The environments are lush and beautiful. It genuinely feels as though Loiste Interactive thought of everything to create an immersive experience for the players.It’s not perfect: There are a number of flaws in the game. However, I believe that this can be explained by the availability of resources for development and the relative inexperience of the development team. Overall, I believe that these flaws can be overlooked but they are notable. First, I was worried that I couldn’t even start the game. I don’t necessarily put games straight onto my SSD. Consequently, I put INFRA onto my HDD and it stayed there. When I first loaded up the game I got long periods of black screens to the point where I quit the game multiple times believing that the game had crashed on me. I believe on the third or fourth attempt I just said to hell with it and got myself a drink. I soon heard the game begin – so if this happens to you please wait. Secondly, the voice acting is poor. However, thankfully once you get out of the office there isn’t a lot of it and what little of it there is is bearable. That office seen, though, felt as though the voice actors didn’t particularly care for the job that they were doing. Not a good beginning. There are also grammatical errors in the English within the game but not to the point where you are dumbfounded at what is being said.INFRA is one of the best new Indie games on Steam. It offers significant gameplay value at its current cost and is perfect for those of you who enjoy good adventure puzzle games with some horror thrown in for good measure. If you don’t buy it now because you’re waiting for the second part of the game to be released then you should at the very least put it on your wishlist.For similar reviews and our daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

All puzzles it has can be divided in two groups - 'figure this machine' and 'common logic'. Both are pretty scarce. Machine puzzles operate on the same simplified real world logic as other puzzles. They are barely 'gamey' and barely enjoyable with some exceptions where it's either 'gamey' or enjoyable. Valves and boxes. Don't buy for puzzles, you've been warned.Infra looks good enough with it's incredible attention to detail. Though it's not that techy, since it's just good old source engine. And performance is top notch being built on ancient engine.Sounds are competent and they really build up environment and add feeling of space (use headphones pls), music is nothing to write home about, but it suits the game well.The only flaw (and it is a major one) is 'action' sections. Be it a rafting through tunnels or just 'escape before stuff blows up'. They not only don't fit the game since it's pretty slow paced explorative expreince, they are badly designed and they give away that it's not A-class title (also they look pretty bad too, in comparison to overall attention to detail in Infra). You often need to simply memorize where to go after numerous attempts. Well, not all such sections are bad (basically first one with flood gates, rafting one and walter's underground with explosions are crimes against humanity), some are great (runoff puzzle) and some are tolerable (sewers cave-in). You'll need a bit of patience for those.All in all for it's low price you get a 40-50 hours of exploration (as of today only 2/3 of the game is available - around 20-30 hours).If exploration is your thing - buy it right now. The game is packed. So big you'll feel like you rob a developer for that price to content ratio.p.s.: If puzzles is your thing... Skip. It's not a puzzle game.

												This is a hard game to recommend, even though there were a LOT of good things about it.  I think this is a unique setting for a game and everything in the game looks great.  I loved poking around in these old crumbling and rusting contrete buildings/structures.  There is a compelling framework for a great game... Slight spoiler/valuble tip:  Early in the game, touching most water is an insta-kill (GTA3 like, even).  But then later in the game, you have to jump off a ledge into murky water and, suprise, you can walk around no problem.  I had to watch a youtube video for that.That could be better, or there could be a compelling story that keeps you moving forward.  There's a attempt at a plot, but the scraps are so far and few between that you don't remember any the names or what's going on.  There are newspaper articles that have a lot of background info, and they have general world building, but I couldn't put the pieces together.  Maybe the designer looked at this stuff as a whole, but when it was spread over 10ish hours of gameplay all the intricacies and the interconnected bits were lost.So again, this is sort of a regrettable not recommended.  I wanted to like it, but in the end I was just watching youtube videos almost right away because I wanted to finish it.  I think the designers (or you) should take a look at SOMA.  I wasn't a fan of the horror element, but it also had a beautiful world, lots of walking, and similar mechanics.  But there was a compelling story, the puzzles you solved accomplished something, and there was a lot less backtracking.

												INFRA Is a game with a lot of good concepts and a style that looks somewhat similar to the Stanley Parable and Half Life 2, with a lot of simplified almost to clean models and well as a reasonable amount of appropriate clutter items to flesh out a scene.  The central story encourages exploring never nook and the game does not disappoint, at least at first.  If you go into the game assuming a certain level of exploration with fix it logic then you will enjoy much of this game, but will likely find your enjoyment level to drop significantly around the end of chapter 3/beginning of chapter 4 and I'll explain why.  There are two primary problems with the game's current set up.  The first is the scope of what is going on, which balloons in a hurry and in a way that loses credibility due to where its happening, which is a shame.  If handled on a much slower build and if the game had kept its locations remote it would have worked brilliantly.  I will avoid any spoilers in this this explanation but just know that the locations in this game start off remote, possibility believable that they have been abandoned for decades, and then moves on to locations that smack in the middle of cities in a way that they can't have been ignored that long.  The size of the levels also grows significantly, which makes there placement less credible.  If they had remained remote it would have worked much better.  The second and id would argue bigger problem is that the physics engine, or physics interactions suck.  This will not be a problem until the point I mentioned above, where you will start to encounter area after area of instant death traps which require precise object placement.  There is no rotate option, the items bounce around and one mistake and your back to your last save.  These sections, unlike the exploration and fixit puzzles that i enjoyed so much, rapidly drained my enjoyment of the game, as they involved huge set pieces of "how do i get out of here".  The lack of inventory interface is irksome, but i can understand the thematic reason for it.  As the character mentioned how many packs of batteries he has one picking a new set up.  A command to have character due a verbal check would have been useful.To the developer, I see a lot of good things in this game and I hope the second part is ever better.  If you don’t; want to add in human models keep the locations remote.  But please rework the controls and get rid of the water hazards.  Your strength is in useful interactive exploration, not physics obstacles.To the rest of you, despite its flaws, I would give it try, just be aware the flaws are there

Basic InformationTitle: INFRAGenre: Adventure, IndieDeveloper: Loiste Interactive Publisher: Loiste Interactive	Release Date: 15 Jan, 2016Basic OverviewInfra is a very atmospheric, first-person adventure game, with some puzzles and some platforming. The puzzles themselves have a wide range, from the most simplistic, to rather challenging. The game itself looks great, the graphics and shaders really seemed to take effect to the game itself. There seems to have been a lot of work on everything on this game, from the stunning graphics and scenery to the puzzles.Game PlayThis game focuses mostly on puzzles, and have some puzzle-platforming parts of the game as well. It makes a nice change to the game rather than sticking to just puzzles all the time. Some of the puzzles that you may encounter in this game are either simplistic or rather difficult. The challenge of the game increases as you proceed through the game, the puzzles get harder and therefore require you to think more about how to solve them. The game starts at a slow pace in the way of solving puzzles, and the ouzzles seem to be one right after the other. The game itself isn't completely open world, but there is a decent amount of areas to explore if you are the kind of person who likes exploring places that aren't always 100% necessary to do so. A point that I didn't like about the rather difficult puzzles where the situations where you would just die over and over again until you can figure out what to do. This got me rather fustrated and made me stop playing for a small remainder of time. Thankfully this game has autosave checkpoints which slightly lowered my furstration when dying over and over but still pushed me enough to make me stop playing for a little bit. The story line of the game is really good, it's very interesting and made me come back to play more if I ever did break out of fustration at times of the game.GraphicsThe graphics of this game are absolutely stunning. I can't even begin to imagine how much work the developers must've put into this to make it look as good as it does. Although most of the game will be going into dark and gloomy places, there still seems to be a lot of work been put into this game. When you are platforming on the game, it gives you a chance to see more of the contryside that you couldn't normally see.Music & SoundThe game really does well when it comes to the sounds when you are in the different locations of the game, depending if you are outside or inside a dark gloomy area, it really helps set the atmosphere up for the game. The sounds of the birds whistling when you are outdoors really makes it feel like a peaceful place to be in, along with the soundtrack which gives off a really nice ambient type of music (Deluxe edition).ConclusionInfra is a very atmospheric and fun game to play. With it's vast amount of puzzles varied difficulty on some of the parts of the game, along with all of the sounds that you hear outside and in other places that set the atmosphere of thw game all togehter. Would recommend those of you who like puzzle games to definatly buy this!For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Good Games Giveaways & Reviews curator group here.

Is this poor map design, a challenge or did I miss some important controls when I would always end up in the river when taking what seemed to be a short cut?As for the puzzles and the story, well, I lost interest in them. The puzzles became something I had to do in order to open a door to continue and I couldn't get any joy out of that after a while. Something was missing to keep me interested and motivated, something didn't make the world believable. Still, I managed to complete the game, though I could have just as easily given up after losing interest.While investigating the problems of the infrastructure and corruption behind it seemed like a nice idea, it felt like a bad hobby (because of not getting anything in return, just to advance to next location). There was no benefit in doing it. Also there is some illogical aspect in this, a hole in the bridge or a wall should be reported but blocked fire escapes and other clear structural defect and dangerous things shouldn't be? I really couldn't understand sometimes what I was supposed to document and what not.So, who should buy this game? If you like exploring and solving puzzles, maybe this is your game. The idea had novelty value, but somehow the end result didn't feel like a ready game. So maybe instead of part 2, this part 1 should be finished?

												Most of this review was written after playing part 1, but main issues are still present in part 2. As such, I can't really recommend this game. The game seems to have not been playtested with people coming into the game completely blind.- Distractingly amateurish voice acting- Graphics look somewhat outdated, partly because of the Source engine- Still no adjusting options like mouse sensitivity when inside the game. Why?!- Long loading times were a problem, but they're better now. First boot will still take a long time.- Many levels have dead end sections of no importance- Valves turn agonizingly slowly, and there are plenty of them- Some key items are easily missable, or even hidden to an extent- Is it safe for me to walk here? Better toss a coin- Time critical sections are extremely confusing, needing many restarts- A completely pointless rafting sectionIf I'd have to sum up INFRA in one word, it would be confusion. Most of my playtime was spent backtracking, trying to search every corner for something to interact with or take with me, staring at panels and walls for numbers, trying a route and dying, only to figure out that the last save was 5 minutes ago, retrying a solution only to fail because of the controls, figuring out there's a path that has been deadly in other instances, but now all of a sudden it's safe to traverse etc.Games like Portal and Braid can have moments of simply staring at the puzzle, but in those situations you know what the goal is, and thinking about the problem takes you closer to the solution. In INFRA, there were plenty of times where I had no idea what I was supposed to do or where I was supposed to go. Many of the puzzles in INFRA take the form of overly complicated machinery that needs certain switches and buttons in certain positions, or certain pipes need to be either opened or closed via slowly turning valves somewhere, or sometimes you need to find the valve itself somewhere and find where to stick that valve. If there are any locked doors, you bet there are easy to miss keys and keycards somewhere. The same puzzle types get very old very quickly.It's kind of sad to write this kind of review, as INFRA was one of the first games I witnessed in Steam Greenlight, and it seemed like a fresh idea with plenty of potential. Now INFRA seems more like a TC mod for Half-Life 2 rather than a fully fledged game in it's own right, and things haven't improved in part 2.

Anyways I go back down there flip the lever run up hop over a wall instead of just have it locked like another door I had to get the keys for earlier, go into some cabin that's been abandoned for years in the most unlikely way possible (climb a ladder up the roof and fall down on some sort of wood shutter that's held by some string strong enough to hold our weight to climb into the attic) get some guys keys into a mineshaft that for some reason is related to the power system we're inspecting.That was only a PART of my time with Chapter 2.  3 from what I played involved a switch puzzle that only existed because the lines weren't managed professionally, and something that was literally filp all the switches on, turn it on, then hit reset and you know all this by reading a note placed right next to it all.  It was then I realised that this game is a puzzle game based on cheap tricks that are 'puzzles' only because it takes a minute at most for you to turn something on and it was also based on hiding what you're actually supposed to do, I thought I was only investigating the actual power plant, why am I in a cave now.  I only got more confused by this game as it went on.Alright now time for the graphics, while they're actually good for an indie game and the price I cant say I enjoyed a lot of the enviorment design, in chapter one the graphics were the poorest some models looked phoned in and textures were sometimes large part solid color, that was the worse of it, chapter 2 the starting area sums it up pretty well. 												INFRA is not my usual type of game - I normally stick to RTS titles. Yet the concept of walking through dilapadated ruins looking for dangerous cracks and things out of place sucked me in, and I'm very glad it did! Having played through Part 1 (Part 2 is due later and will not be DLC but an integral part of the game, which will rise in price when it is released, so buying now may save you!) I would say that my favourite part of INFRA is the incredible atmosphere the game manages to create. An effective mix of impressive visuals and ambient effects bring to life the game's juxtaposition of the natural and artificial landscapes - so you'll emerge from a tunnel to see the decaying entrace behind is encrusted in trees and plants just as a slightly haunting tune plays, giving a pleasantly melancholy feeling. The game puzzles are nice and varied, with clever use of the same elements to prevent everything from feeling too 'samey'. The game plot appears threadbare at first, but as the game progresses you can find out a lot more - nothing is presented explicitly, but if you piece together the scattered documents you find along the game you can put it all together, culminating in the final setpiece which sets the game up nicely for Part 2. The game has pretty good replay value, with a good mix of hidden achievements and collectibles (e.g. when going off the game path to some inaccessible place you'll sometimes find a geocache). After finishing my first playthrough I really want to go through again and find every little detail! Overall, INFRA is a steal for its price - I'd thoroughly recommend it

												INFRA is not my usual type of game - I normally stick to RTS titles. Yet the concept of walking through dilapadated ruins looking for dangerous cracks and things out of place sucked me in, and I'm very glad it did! Having played through Part 1 (Part 2 is due later and will not be DLC but an integral part of the game, which will rise in price when it is released, so buying now may save you!) I would say that my favourite part of INFRA is the incredible atmosphere the game manages to create. An effective mix of impressive visuals and ambient effects bring to life the game's juxtaposition of the natural and artificial landscapes - so you'll emerge from a tunnel to see the decaying entrace behind is encrusted in trees and plants just as a slightly haunting tune plays, giving a pleasantly melancholy feeling. The game puzzles are nice and varied, with clever use of the same elements to prevent everything from feeling too 'samey'. The game plot appears threadbare at first, but as the game progresses you can find out a lot more - nothing is presented explicitly, but if you piece together the scattered documents you find along the game you can put it all together, culminating in the final setpiece which sets the game up nicely for Part 2. The game has pretty good replay value, with a good mix of hidden achievements and collectibles (e.g. when going off the game path to some inaccessible place you'll sometimes find a geocache). After finishing my first playthrough I really want to go through again and find every little detail! Overall, INFRA is a steal for its price - I'd thoroughly recommend it
